member.name: T:Microsoft.PowerShell.Commands.GetAclCommand
member.summary: Defines the implementation of the 'get-acl' cmdlet. This cmdlet gets the security descriptor of an item at the specified path.

member.name: M:Microsoft.PowerShell.Commands.GetAclCommand.#ctor
member.summary: Initialzes a new instance of the GetAclCommand class. Sets the default path to the current location.

member.name: M:Microsoft.PowerShell.Commands.GetAclCommand.ProcessRecord
member.summary: Processes records from the input pipeline. For each input file, the command retrieves its corresponding security descriptor.

member.name: P:Microsoft.PowerShell.Commands.GetAclCommand.Path
member.summary: Gets or sets the path of the item for which to obtain the security descriptor. Default is the current location.

member.name: P:Microsoft.PowerShell.Commands.GetAclCommand.InputObject
member.summary: InputObject Parameter Gets or sets the inputObject for which to obtain the security descriptor

member.name: P:Microsoft.PowerShell.Commands.GetAclCommand.LiteralPath
member.summary: Gets or sets the literal path of the item for which to obtain the security descriptor. Default is the current location.

member.name: P:Microsoft.PowerShell.Commands.GetAclCommand.Audit
member.summary: Gets or sets the audit flag of the command. This flag determines if audit rules should also be retrieved.

member.name: P:Microsoft.PowerShell.Commands.GetAclCommand.AllCentralAccessPolicies
member.summary: Gets or sets the AllCentralAccessPolicies flag of the command. This flag determines whether the information about all central access policies available on the machine should be displayed.

member.name: T:Microsoft.PowerShell.Commands.SetAclCommand
member.summary: Defines the implementation of the 'set-acl' cmdlet. This cmdlet sets the security descriptor of an item at the specified path.

member.name: M:Microsoft.PowerShell.Commands.SetAclCommand.GetEmptySacl
member.summary: Returns a newly allocated SACL with no ACEs in it. Free the returned SACL by calling Marshal.FreeHGlobal.

member.name: M:Microsoft.PowerShell.Commands.SetAclCommand.GetSaclWithCapId(System.String)
member.summary: Returns a newly allocated SACL with the supplied CAPID in it. Free the returned SACL by calling Marshal.FreeHGlobal.

member.name: M:Microsoft.PowerShell.Commands.SetAclCommand.GetTokenWithEnabledPrivilege(System.String,System.Management.Automation.Security.NativeMethods.TOKEN_PRIVILEGE)
member.summary: Returns the current thread or process token with the specified privilege enabled and the previous state of this privilege. Free the returned token by calling NativeMethods.CloseHandle.

members.member: Processes records from the input pipeline. For each input file, the command sets its security descriptor to the specified Access Control List (ACL).

member.summary: InputObject Parameter Gets or sets the inputObject for which to set the security descriptor

member.summary: Gets or sets the literal path of the item for which to set the security descriptor.

member.summary: Gets or sets the security descriptor object to be set on the target item(s).

member.summary: Gets or sets the central access policy to be set on the target item(s).

member.summary: Clears the central access policy applied on the target item(s).

member.name: P:Microsoft.PowerShell.Commands.SetAclCommand.Passthru
member.summary: Gets or sets the Passthru flag for the operation. If true, the security descriptor is also passed down the output pipeline.

member.name: T:Microsoft.PowerShell.Commands.CertificateProviderDynamicParameters
member.summary:
Defines the Certificate Provider dynamic parameters.
We only support one dynamic parameter for Win 7 and earlier: CodeSigningCert If provided, we only return certificates valid for signing code or scripts.
For Win 8 and later, we also support: SSLServerAuthentication If provided, only return certificates valid for server authentication.
DnsName If provided, only return certificates matching the supplied DNS Name.
Eku If provided, only return certificates containing all of the OIDs supplied.
ExpiringInDays If provided, only return certificates expiring within the specified number of days.

member.name: P:Microsoft.PowerShell.Commands.CertificateProviderDynamicParameters.CodeSigningCert
member.summary: switch that controls whether we only return code signing certs.

member.name: P:Microsoft.PowerShell.Commands.CertificateProviderDynamicParameters.SSLServerAuthentication
member.summary: switch that controls whether we only return code signing certs.

member.name: P:Microsoft.PowerShell.Commands.CertificateProviderDynamicParameters.DnsName
member.summary: string to filter certs by DNSName Expected content is a single DNS Name that may start and/or end with '*': "contoso.com" or "*toso.c*"

member.name: P:Microsoft.PowerShell.Commands.CertificateProviderDynamicParameters.Eku
member.summary: string to filter certs by EKU Expected content is one or more OID strings: "1.3.6.1.5.5.7.3.1", etc. For a cert to match, it must be valid for all listed OIDs.

member.name: P:Microsoft.PowerShell.Commands.CertificateProviderDynamicParameters.ExpiringInDays
member.summary: string to filter certs by the number of valid days Expected content is a non-negative integer. "0" matches all certs that have already expired. "1" matches all certs that are currently valid and will expire by midnight tonight (local time).

member.name: T:Microsoft.PowerShell.Commands.ProviderRemoveItemDynamicParameters
member.summary:
Defines the Certificate Provider remove-item dynamic parameters.
Currently, we only support one dynamic parameter: DeleteKey If provided, we will delete the private key when we remove a certificate

member.name: P:Microsoft.PowerShell.Commands.ProviderRemoveItemDynamicParameters.DeleteKey
member.summary: switch that controls whether we should delete private key when remove a certificate

member.name: F:Microsoft.PowerShell.Commands.CertificateProvider.staticLock
member.summary: lock that guards access to the following static members -- storeLocations -- pathCache

member.name: F:Microsoft.PowerShell.Commands.CertificateProvider.storeLocations
member.summary:
list of store locations. They do not change once initialized.
Synchronized on staticLock

member.name: F:Microsoft.PowerShell.Commands.CertificateProvider.pathCache
member.summary:
cache that stores paths and their associated objects.
key is full path to store-location/store/certificate value is X509StoreLocation/X509NativeStore/X509Certificate2 object
Synchronized on staticLock

member.name: F:Microsoft.PowerShell.Commands.CertificateProvider.fIsWin8AndAbove
member.summary: downlevel support flag

member.name: F:Microsoft.PowerShell.Commands.CertificateProvider.pathSeparators
member.summary: we allow either / or \ to be the path separator

member.name: F:Microsoft.PowerShell.Commands.CertificateProvider.storeCache
member.summary: Cache the store handle to avoid repeated CertOpenStore calls.

member.name: F:Microsoft.PowerShell.Commands.CertificateProvider.certPathRegex
member.summary: On demand create the Regex to avoid a hit to startup perf.
member.remarks: Note, its OK that staticLock is being used here because only IsValidPath is calling this static property so we shouldn't have any deadlocks due to other locked static members calling this property.

member.name: M:Microsoft.PowerShell.Commands.CertificateProvider.#ctor
member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the CertificateProvider class. This initializes the default certificate store locations.

member.name: M:Microsoft.PowerShell.Commands.CertificateProvider.RemoveItem(System.String,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Removes an item at the specified path
member.param: The path of the item to remove.
member.returns: Nothing.
member.exception: path is null or empty. destination is null or empty.

member.name: M:Microsoft.PowerShell.Commands.CertificateProvider.RemoveItemDynamicParameters(System.String,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Gets the dynamic parameters for remove-item on the Certificate Provider. We currently only support one dynamic parameter, "DeleteKey," that delete private key when we delete a certificate.
member.param: If the path was specified on the command line, this is the path to the item for which to get the dynamic parameters.
member.returns: An object that has properties and fields decorated with parsing attributes similar to a cmdlet class.

member.name: M:Microsoft.PowerShell.Commands.CertificateProvider.MoveItem(System.String,System.String)
member.summary: Moves an item at the specified path to the given destination.
member.param: The path of the item to move.
member.returns: Nothing. Moved items are written to the context's pipeline.
member.exception: path is null or empty. destination is null or empty.

member.name: M:Microsoft.PowerShell.Commands.CertificateProvider.NewItem(System.String,System.String,System.Object)
member.summary: Creates a certificate store with the given path.
member.remarks: New-Item doesn't go through the method "ItemExists". But for the CertificateProvider, New-Item can create an X509Store and return it, and the user can access the certificates within the store via its property "Certificates". We want the extra new properties of the X509Certificate2 objects to be shown to the user, so we also need to import the PKI module in this method, if we haven't tried it yet.
member.param: The path of the certificate store to create.
member.returns: Nothing. The new certificate store object is written to the context's pipeline.

member.name: M:Microsoft.PowerShell.Commands.CertificateProvider.InitializeDefaultDrives
member.summary: Initializes the cert: drive.
member.returns: A collection that contains the PSDriveInfo object that represents the cert: drive.

member.name: M:Microsoft.PowerShell.Commands.CertificateProvider.HasChildItems(System.String)
member.summary: Determines if the item at the given path is a store-location or store with items in it.
member.param: The full path to the item.
member.returns: True if the path refers to a store location, or store that contains certificates. False otherwise.
member.exception: This exception can be thrown if any cryptographic error occurs. It is not possible to know exactly what went wrong. This is because of the way CryptographicException is designed. Some example reasons include: -- certificate is invalid -- certificate has no private key -- certificate password mismatch

member.name: M:Microsoft.PowerShell.Commands.CertificateProvider.IsValidPath(System.String)
member.summary: Determines if the specified path is syntactically and semantically valid. An example path looks like this: cert:\CurrentUser\My\5F98EBBFE735CDDAE00E33E0FD69050EF9220254
member.param: The path of the item to check.
member.returns: True if the path is valid, false otherwise.

member.name: M:Microsoft.PowerShell.Commands.CertificateProvider.ItemExists(System.String)
member.summary: Determines if the store location, store, or certificate exists at the specified path.
member.remarks: The method ItemExists will be hit by all built-in cmdlets that interact with the CertificateProvider except for the New-Item. They are: Get-ChildItem Set-Location Push-Location Pop-Location Move-Item Invoke-Item Get-Item Remove-Item So we import the PKI module in this method if we haven't tried yet.
member.param: The path of the item to check.
member.returns: True if a the store location, store, or certificate exists at the specified path. False otherwise.
member.exception: This exception can be thrown if any cryptographic error occurs. It is not possible to know exactly what went wrong. This is because of the way CryptographicException is designed. Possible reasons: -- certificate is invalid -- certificate has no private key -- certificate password mismatch -- etc

member.name: M:Microsoft.PowerShell.Commands.CertificateProvider.GetItem(System.String)
member.summary: Gets the store location, store, or certificate at the specified path.
member.param: The path of the item to retrieve.
member.exception: This exception can be thrown if any cryptographic error occurs. It is not possible to know exactly what went wrong. This is because of the way CryptographicException is designed. Possible reasons: -- certificate is invalid -- certificate has no private key -- certificate password mismatch -- etc

member.name: M:Microsoft.PowerShell.Commands.CertificateProvider.GetParentPath(System.String,System.String)
member.summary: Gets the parent of the given path.
member.param: The path of which to get the parent.
member.returns: The parent of the given path.

member.name: M:Microsoft.PowerShell.Commands.CertificateProvider.GetChildName(System.String)
member.summary: Gets the name of the leaf element of the specified path.
member.param: The fully qualified path to the item.
member.returns: The leaf element of the specified path.

member.name: M:Microsoft.PowerShell.Commands.CertificateProvider.AttemptToImportPkiModule
member.summary: We want to import the PKI module explicitly because a type for X509Certificate is defined in the PKI module that add new properties to the X509Certificate2 objects. We want to show those new properties to the user without requiring someone to force the loading of this module.

member.name: M:Microsoft.PowerShell.Commands.CertificateProvider.InvokeDefaultAction(System.String)
member.summary: Invokes the certificate management UI (certmgr.msc) for any path.

member.summary: Gets the child items of a given store, or location.

If true, recursively enumerates the child items as well.

Possible reasons: -- certificate is invalid -- certificate has no private key -- certificate password mismatch -- etc

member.exception: This exception can be thrown if any cryptographic error occurs. It is not possible to know exactly what went wrong. This is because of the way CryptographicException is designed. Possible reasons: -- certificate is invalid -- certificate has no private key -- certificate password mismatch -- etc

member.exception: This exception can be thrown if any cryptographic error occurs. It is not possible to know exactly what went wrong. This is because of the way CryptographicException is designed. member.name: M:Microsoft.PowerShell.Commands.Crypt32Helpers.CertEnumSystemStoreCallBack(System.String,System.UInt32,System.IntPtr,System.IntPtr,System.IntPtr)
member.summary:
call back function used by CertEnumSystemStore
Currently, there is no managed support for enumerating store names on a machine. We use the win32 function CertEnumSystemStore() to get a list of stores for a given context.
Each time this callback is called, we add the passed store name to the list of stores

member.name: T:Microsoft.PowerShell.Commands.GetExecutionPolicyCommand
member.summary:
Defines the implementation of the 'Get-ExecutionPolicy' cmdlet. This cmdlet gets the effective execution policy of the shell.
In priority-order (highest priority first,) these come from: - Machine-wide Group Policy - Current-user Group Policy - Current session preference - Current user machine preference - Local machine preference

member.name: M:Microsoft.PowerShell.Commands.GetExecutionPolicyCommand.BeginProcessing
member.summary: Outputs the execution policy.

member.name: P:Microsoft.PowerShell.Commands.GetExecutionPolicyCommand.Scope
member.summary: Gets or sets the scope of the execution policy.

member.name: P:Microsoft.PowerShell.Commands.GetExecutionPolicyCommand.List
member.summary: Gets or sets the List parameter, which lists all scopes and their execution policies.

member.name: T:Microsoft.PowerShell.Commands.SetExecutionPolicyCommand
member.summary:
Defines the implementation of the 'Set-ExecutionPolicy' cmdlet. This cmdlet sets the local preference for the execution policy of the shell.
The execution policy may be overridden by settings in Group Policy. If the Group Policy setting overrides the desired behaviour, the Cmdlet generates a terminating error.

member.name: M:Microsoft.PowerShell.Commands.SetExecutionPolicyCommand.BeginProcessing
member.summary: Sets the execution policy (validation).

member.name: M:Microsoft.PowerShell.Commands.SetExecutionPolicyCommand.ProcessRecord
member.summary: Set the desired execution policy.

member.name: P:Microsoft.PowerShell.Commands.SetExecutionPolicyCommand.ExecutionPolicy
member.summary: Gets or sets the execution policy that the user requests.

member.name: P:Microsoft.PowerShell.Commands.SetExecutionPolicyCommand.Scope
member.summary: Gets or sets the scope of the execution policy.

member.name: P:Microsoft.PowerShell.Commands.SetExecutionPolicyCommand.Force
member.summary: Specifies whether to force the execution policy change.

member.summary: association between SigningOption.* values and the corresponding string names.

member.summary: get SigningOption value corresponding to a string name
member.returns: SigningOption

member.summary: Gets or sets the certificate with which to sign the file.

member.name: P:Microsoft.PowerShell.Commands.SetAuthenticodeSignatureCommand.IncludeChain
member.summary:
Gets or sets the additional certificates to include in the digital signature. Use 'signer' to include only the signer's certificate. Use 'notroot' to include all certificates in the certificate chain, except for the root authority. Use 'all' to include all certificates in the certificate chain.
Defaults to 'notroot'.

member.name: P:Microsoft.PowerShell.Commands.SetAuthenticodeSignatureCommand.TimestampServer
member.summary: Gets or sets the Url of the time stamping server. The time stamping server certifies the exact time that the certificate was added to the file.

member.name: P:Microsoft.PowerShell.Commands.SetAuthenticodeSignatureCommand.HashAlgorithm
member.summary: Gets or sets the hash algorithm used for signing. This string value must represent the name of a Cryptographic Algorithm Identifier supported by Windows.

member.name: P:Microsoft.PowerShell.Commands.SetAuthenticodeSignatureCommand.Force
member.summary: Property that sets force parameter.

member.summary: Defines the base class from which all SecureString import and export commands are derived.

member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the ConvertFromToSecureStringCommandBase class.

member.summary: Gets or sets the SecureString version of the encryption key used by the SecureString cmdlets.

member.summary: Gets or sets the byte version of the encryption key used by the SecureString cmdlets.

member.name: T:Microsoft.PowerShell.Commands.ConvertFromSecureStringCommand
member.summary: Defines the implementation of the 'ConvertFrom-SecureString' cmdlet. This cmdlet exports a new SecureString -- one that represents text that should be kept confidential. The text is encrypted for privacy when being used, and deleted from computer memory when no longer needed. When no key is specified, the command uses the DPAPI to encrypt the string. When a key is specified, the command uses the Rijndael algorithm to encrypt the string.

member.name: M:Microsoft.PowerShell.Commands.ConvertFromSecureStringCommand.#ctor
member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the ExportSecureStringCommand class

member.name: M:Microsoft.PowerShell.Commands.ConvertFromSecureStringCommand.ProcessRecord
member.summary: Processes records from the input pipeline. For each input object, the command encrypts and exports the object.

member.name: P:Microsoft.PowerShell.Commands.ConvertFromSecureStringCommand.SecureString
member.summary: Gets or sets the secure string to be exported.

member.name: T:Microsoft.PowerShell.Commands.ConvertToSecureStringCommand
member.summary: Defines the implementation of the 'ConvertTo-SecureString' cmdlet. This cmdlet imports a new SecureString from encrypted data -- one that represents text that should be kept confidential. The text is encrypted for privacy when being used, and deleted from computer memory when no longer needed. When no key is specified, the command uses the DPAPI to decrypt the data. When a key is specified, the command uses the Rijndael algorithm to decrypt the data.

member.name: M:Microsoft.PowerShell.Commands.ConvertToSecureStringCommand.#ctor
member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the ImportSecureStringCommand class.

member.name: M:Microsoft.PowerShell.Commands.ConvertToSecureStringCommand.ProcessRecord
member.summary: Processes records from the input pipeline. For each input object, the command decrypts the data, then exports a new SecureString created from the object.

member.name: P:Microsoft.PowerShell.Commands.ConvertToSecureStringCommand.String
member.summary: Gets or sets the unsecured string to be imported.

member.name: P:Microsoft.PowerShell.Commands.ConvertToSecureStringCommand.AsPlainText
member.summary: Gets or sets the flag that marks the unsecured string as a plain text string.

member.name: P:Microsoft.PowerShell.Commands.ConvertToSecureStringCommand.Force
member.summary: Gets or sets the flag that will force the import of a plaintext unsecured string.

member.returns: user input as secure string

member.name: M:Microsoft.PowerShell.SecurityUtils.GetStringFromSecureString(System.Security.SecureString)
member.summary:
get plain text string from a SecureString
This function will not be required once all of the methods that we call accept a SecureString. The list below has classes/methods that will be changed to accept a SecureString after Whidbey beta1
-- X509Certificate2.Import (String, String, X509KeyStorageFlags) (DCR #33007 in the DevDiv Schedule db)
-- NetworkCredential(string, string);
member.returns: a string representing clear-text equivalent of ss

member.name: P:ExecutionPolicyCommands.ExecutionPolicyOverridden
member.summary: Looks up a localized string similar to Windows PowerShell updated your execution policy successfully, but the setting is overridden by a policy defined at a more specific scope. Due to the override, your shell will retain its current effective execution policy of {0}. Type "Get-ExecutionPolicy -List" to view your execution policy settings. For more information please see "Get-Help Set-ExecutionPolicy"..

member.name: P:ExecutionPolicyCommands.ExecutionPolicyOverriddenRecommendedAction
member.summary: Looks up a localized string similar to Contact your system administrator..

member.name: P:ExecutionPolicyCommands.ListAndScopeSpecified
member.summary: Looks up a localized string similar to Cannot get execution policy. Specify only the List or Scope parameters..

member.name: P:ExecutionPolicyCommands.SetExecutionPolicyCaption
member.summary: Looks up a localized string similar to Execution Policy Change.

member.name: P:ExecutionPolicyCommands.SetExecutionPolicyQuery
member.summary: Looks up a localized string similar to The execution policy helps protect you from scripts that you do not trust. Changing the execution policy might expose you to the security risks described in the about_Execution_Policies help topic at http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=135170. Do you want to change the execution policy?.
